newsitem.title: UK: GNI sees 1996/97 cocoa deficit of 180,000T.
newsitem.headline: GNI sees 1996/97 cocoa deficit of 180,000T.

text.p: World cocoa supply may post a deficit of 180,000 tonnes in 1996/97 (Oct/Sept) compared with an estimated surplus of 161,000 tonnes in 1995/96, broker GNI said.
The brokerage said in a report that production from top grower Ivory Coast would total around 950,000 tonnes this season, down from record 1.20 million last season.
It put the net global crop at 2.559 million tonnes, down 10.39 percent from 1995/96's 2.856 million.
On the demand side, grinding growth is expected to moderate to 1.65 percent in 1996/97 to 2.729 million.
Thus, a projected supply shortfall of 180,000 tonnes would reduce world stocks to 34 percent of annual consumption from 42 percent.
GNI said the deficit figure of 180,000 should be regarded as a mid-point of the likely outcome. It saw a range of deficit outcomes of between 110,00 and 250,000.

"It is however important for anyone reviewing any cocoa forecast at this point in time to realise that the margin of error is still very high," it said. -- Jalil Hamid, London newsroom +44 171 542 4985
